thread.title: Longhorns grind out win in rain over Kansas State

author: chron.com
title: Longhorns grind out win in rain over Kansas State
text:

(AP Photo/Michael Thomas) Texas defensive back Jason Hall (31), with help from John Bonney (24), knocks away a pass intended for Kansas State receiver Kody Cook (19) during the first half of an NCAA college football game, Saturday, Oct. ... more Image 6 of 13 Texas head coach Charlie Strong watches his team in the rain before the start of an NCAA college football game against Kansas State, Saturday, Oct. 24, 2015, in Austin, Texas. (AP Photo/Michael ... more Image 12 of 13 A Texas fan watches in the rain during the first half of an NCAA college football game against Kansas State, Saturday, Oct. 24, 2015, in Austin, Texas. (AP Photo/Michael Thomas) A Texas fan watches in the rain during the first half of an NCAA college football game against Kansas State, Saturday, Oct. 24, 2015, in Austin, Texas. (AP Photo/Michael Thomas) Photo: Michael Thomas, Associated Press Image 13 of 13 Longhorns grind out win in rain over Kansas State 1 / 13 Back to Gallery AUSTIN – Jerrod Heard said Texas wanted to win “nasty.” Saturday against Kansas State, that’s exactly what the Longhorns did.
On a day when a steady downpour made passing difficult and finesse almost impossible, UT used a steady does of rugged, gritty simplicity to beat the Wildcats 23-9 at Royal-Memorial Stadium.
The Longhorns didn’t complete a pass beyond the line of scrimmage until midway through the third quarter, but it didn’t matter. With Jonathan Gray rushing for 103 yards and Heard adding 61, all they needed to do was control the clock as the UT defense consistently shut down the KSU offense.
RELATED: Box score
UT (3-4 overall, 2-2 in the Big 12) built a 16-0 lead midway through the second quarter on two touchdown runs by backup quarterback Tyrone Swoopes in the team’s short-yardage package. The Longhorns had multiple opportunities to put the game away early, but several promising scoring drives stall near midfield.
KSU (3-4, 0-4) scored its only points of the first half on a 7-yard pass from Joe Hubener to Dominique Heath. With four minutes left in the fourth quarter, they gained possession with a chance to tie the score, but UT’s Dylan Haines intercepted an ill-advised Hubener lob to end the threat.
Three plays later, Swoopes scored his third touchdown with 1:47 left.
